title: Relates to commencement of a small claims action in New York city civil courts
summary: Requires notice by certified mail with return receipt requested for the commencement of a small claims action in New York city civil courts.
lawSection: New York City Civil Court Act

       Introduced  by  Sen. SAMPSON -- read twice and ordered printed, and when
         printed to be committed to the Committee on Judiciary

       AN ACT to amend the New York  city  civil  court  act,  in  relation  to
         commencement of a small claims action

         THE  PEOPLE OF THE STATE OF NEW YORK, REPRESENTED IN SENATE AND ASSEM-
       BLY, DO ENACT AS FOLLOWS:

    1    Section 1.  The opening paragraph of subdivision (a) of section 1803-A
    2  of the New York city civil court act, as amended by section 35 of part J
    3  of chapter 62 of the laws of 2003, is amended to read as follows:
    4    Commercial claims other than claims arising  out  of  consumer  trans-
    5  actions  shall be commenced upon the payment by the claimant of a filing
    6  fee of twenty-five dollars and the cost of mailings as herein  provided,
    7  without  the  service  of  a summons and, except by special order of the
    8  court, without the service of any pleading other than a required certif-
    9  ication verified as to its  truthfulness  by  the  claimant  on  a  form
   10  prescribed  by  the  state office of court administration and filed with
   11  the clerk, that no more than five such actions or proceedings (including
   12  the instant action or  proceeding)  have  been  instituted  during  that
   13  calendar  month,  and a required statement of its cause of action by the
   14  claimant or someone in its behalf to the clerk,  who  shall  reduce  the
   15  same to a concise, written form and record it in a docket kept especial-
   16  ly  for  such  purpose. Such procedure shall provide that the commercial
   17  claims part of the court shall have  no  jurisdiction  over,  and  shall
   18  dismiss,  any  case  with respect to which the required certification is
   19  not made upon the attempted institution of  the  action  or  proceeding.
   20  Such  procedure shall provide for the sending of notice of such claim by
   21  [ordinary first class mail  and]  certified  mail  with  return  receipt
   22  requested  to  the  party  complained  against  at  his residence, if he
   23  resides within the city of New York, and his residence is known  to  the
   24  claimant,  or  at  his  office or place of regular employment within the

    1  city of New York if he does not reside therein or his  residence  within
    2  the  city of New York is not known to the claimant. [If, after the expi-
    3  ration of twenty-one days, such ordinary first  class  mailing  has  not
    4  been  returned  as  undeliverable, the party complained against shall be
    5  presumed to have received notice  of  such  claim.]  Such  notice  shall
    6  include  a clear description of the procedure for filing a counterclaim,
    7  pursuant to subdivision (d) of this section.
    8    S 2. Subdivision (b) of section 1803-A of  the  New  York  city  civil
    9  court  act, as amended by section 35 of part J of chapter 62 of the laws
   10  of 2003, is amended to read as follows:
   11    (b) (1) Commercial claims in actions arising out  of  consumer  trans-
   12  actions  shall be commenced upon the payment by the claimant of a filing
   13  fee of twenty-five dollars and the cost of mailings as herein  provided,
   14  without  the  service  of  a summons and, except by special order of the
   15  court, without the service of any pleading other than a required  state-
   16  ment  of the cause of action by the claimant or someone on its behalf of
   17  the clerk, who shall reduce the same to a concise written form including
   18  the information required by subdivision (c) of this section,  denominate
   19  it  conspicuously as a consumer transaction, and record it in the docket
   20  marked as a consumer  transaction,  and  by  filing  with  the  clerk  a
   21  required  certificate verified as to its truthfulness by the claimant on
   22  forms prescribed by the state office of court administration.
   23    (2) Such verified certificate shall certify (i) that the claimant  has
   24  mailed  by  ordinary  first class mail to the party complained against a
   25  demand letter, no less than ten days and no more than one hundred eighty
   26  days prior to the commencement of the claim, and (ii) that,  based  upon
   27  information  and  belief, the claimant has not instituted more than five
   28  actions or proceedings (including  the  instant  action  or  proceeding)
   29  during the calendar month.
   30    (3)  A form for the demand letter shall be prescribed and furnished by
   31  the state office of court administration and shall require the following
   32  information: the date of  the  consumer  transaction;  the  amount  that
   33  remains unpaid; a copy of the original debt instrument or other document
   34  underlying  the  debt  and  an  accounting  of all payments, and, if the
   35  claimant was not a party to the  original  transaction,  the  names  and
   36  addresses  of  the  parties to the original transaction; and a statement
   37  that the claimant intends to use this part of  the  court  to  obtain  a
   38  judgment,  that  further  notice  of a hearing date will be sent, unless
   39  payment is received by a specified date, and that the  party  complained
   40  against  will  be  entitled  to  appear  at said hearing and present any
   41  defenses to the claim.
   42    (4) In the  event  that  the  verified  certificate  is  not  properly
   43  completed  by  the  claimant,  the  court  shall not allow the action to
   44  proceed until the verified certificate  is  corrected.  Notice  of  such
   45  claim shall be sent by the clerk by [both ordinary first class mail and]
   46  certified  mail  with  return  receipt requested to the party complained
   47  against at his residence, if he resides within the city of New York, and
   48  his residence is known to the claimant, or at his  office  or  place  of
   49  regular  employment  within  the  city of New York if he does not reside
   50  therein or his residence within the city of New York is not known to the
   51  claimant.  [If, after the expiration of thirty days, such ordinary first
   52  class  mailing  has  not  been  returned  as  undeliverable,  the  party
   53  complained  against  shall  be  presumed to have received notice of such
   54  claim.]
   55    (5) Such procedure shall further provide for an early hearing upon and
   56  determination of such claim. The hearing shall be scheduled in a  manner

       S. 685                              3

    1  which,  to  the extent possible, minimizes the time the party complained
    2  against must be absent from employment. Either party  may  request  that
    3  the hearing be scheduled during evening hours, provided that the hearing
    4  shall  not be scheduled during evening hours if it would cause unreason-
    5  able hardship to either party. The court  shall  not  unreasonably  deny
    6  requests  for evening hearings if such requests are made by the claimant
    7  upon commencement of the action or by the party complained against with-
    8  in fourteen days of receipt of the notice of claim.
    9    S 3. This act shall take effect immediately and shall apply to actions
   10  commenced on and after such date.
